skill.description: Scaffolds new feature modules in DevPrep AI following the 6-folder architecture with proper TypeScript interfaces, path aliases, and quality standards. Use when creating new domains like 'analytics', 'notifications', or any new feature module.

skill.author: ArieGoldkin

security_audit.summary: Pure project scaffolding tool with no network access, no credential exposure risk, and minimal filesystem access confined to the project directory. Uses only standard POSIX utilities for safe file generation.

content.user_title: Scaffold feature modules in DevPrep AI
content.value_statement: Manually creating new feature modules is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill automates module creation with proper structure, TypeScript interfaces, and quality standards enforced from the start.
actual_capabilities: Creates feature modules with proper 6-folder architecture structure
Generates TypeScript components with I-prefixed interfaces
Adds new components to existing modules with barrel exports
Validates module structure and quality standards
Supports path aliases for clean imports (@shared, @lib, @modules)
Enforces naming conventions (PascalCase, kebab-case, I prefix)
limitations: Designed specifically for DevPrep AI project structure
Requires running from project root directory
Module names must use kebab-case format
Does not modify existing code beyond adding exports

use_cases.title: Create new feature modules
use_cases.description: Quickly scaffold a new domain module like analytics or notifications with proper structure.

use_cases.title: Add components to modules
use_cases.description: Add new React components to existing modules with automatic barrel export updates.

use_cases.title: Validate module standards
use_cases.description: Verify that modules follow DevPrep AI conventions for naming, file size, and imports.

prompt_templates.title: Create module
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new module named [your-module-name] using the module-scaffolder skill

prompt_templates.title: Add component
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a [ComponentName] component to the [module-name] module using the module-scaffolder skill

prompt_templates.title: Validate module
prompt_templates.prompt: Validate the [module-name] module using the validate-module.sh script from module-scaffolder

prompt_templates.title: Full module setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a [module-name] module and add the following components: [Component1], [Component2]

output_examples.input: Create a new module named analytics

best_practices: Use brainstorming skill before creating modules to plan the domain structure
Run validate-module.sh after creation to verify quality standards
Follow up with quality-reviewer skill for comprehensive code review
anti_patterns: Do not create cross-module imports - use @shared instead
Do not exceed 180 lines per file - split into smaller components
Do not use 'any' types - use proper TypeScript interfaces

faq.question: What naming formats are required?
faq.answer: Module names use kebab-case (e.g., 'user-profile'), component names use PascalCase (e.g., 'UserCard'), interfaces use I prefix (e.g., 'IUserProps').

faq.question: What directories are created automatically?
faq.answer: Each module gets components/, hooks/, and utils/ directories with barrel exports (index.ts files) and a types.ts file.

faq.question: Can this skill modify existing modules?
faq.answer: The add-component.sh script can add new components to existing modules, but it only creates new files and updates barrel exports.

faq.question: What validation checks are performed?
faq.answer: The validator checks directory structure, file size limits (180 lines), I prefix on interfaces, no 'any' types, and proper import patterns.

faq.question: Does this skill access sensitive data?
faq.answer: No. All file operations are confined to the project frontend/src/modules/ directory with no network access or environment variable reading.

faq.question: How is this different from other scaffolding tools?
faq.answer: This skill is specifically designed for DevPrep AI's 6-folder architecture with enforced quality standards and TypeScript patterns.
